awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Wearable Joint Sounds Sensing for Children with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
awd_abstract_narration:
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common form of childhood arthritis and affects more than 50,000 children in the US. Symptoms and progression of JIA vary greatly between individuals, and there are many possible treatment options depending on the extent of disease. However, diagnosing JIA on a patient-by-patient basis is difficult because reliable tools for assessing the condition do not yet exist, and treatment is often a trial-and-error process. This project will focus on developing wearable joint health-sensing systems that continuously provide data on joint condition, inside and out of the clinic. The PI will focus on advancing the ability to measure and analyze sounds produced by joints during movement. The study will test the hypothesis that joint sounds decrease as joint health improves with therapy. Sounds collected with the wearable devices will be analyzed and compared with patients' joint health to understand possible relationships that can be used to improve diagnostic capabilities. Research and education are integrated through the incorporation of undergraduate research teams in the sensing brace design process and incorporating de-identified dataset analysis in courses at Georgia Institute of Technology. Additionally, the PI will host K-12 teachers in his lab to develop science and engineering modules to take back their classrooms.

Dr. Inan's long-term career goal is to fundamentally advance knowledge in the field of wearable joint health sensing and, thereby, enable personalized therapies and devices for patients with joint disorders, such as arthritis. Toward this goal, Dr. Inan's research objectives are to: (1) design and implement a sensing brace capable of accurately measuring the sounds of the joints in the clinic and at home; (2) investigate algorithms for quantifying differences between the characteristics of joint sounds of patients with JIA and healthy controls; and (3) conduct a feasibility study in patients with JIA by sending the sensing brace home and evaluating the changes in joint sound characteristics measured throughout treatment. The PI's preliminary data suggests that joint sounds can potentially serve as a physiological biomarker for patients with arthritis. The project will first develop a wearable heterogenous sensor array for acoustical sensing with sufficient battery life. Experiments will collect joint sound data from JIA-affected and healthy patients. Graph mining algorithms will be applied to analyze the high-dimensional joint acoustical emissions data and correlate the data with joint health. At project completion, Dr. Inan will have developed a new physiological measurement tool for diagnosing and treating JIA patients based on their specific symptoms and responses to treatment, ultimately improving their quality of life and minimizing permanent joint damage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background

The goal of this research is to advance the knowledge of joint acoustic emissions (JAEs) in children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), which can ultimately lead to improved treatments for JIA. JIA is the most common form of childhood arthritis and one of the most common chronic pediatric conditions. The characteristic joint damage caused by JIA can affect those afflicted for their entire life. However, this joint damage and correlated symptoms in later life can largely be avoided with early interventions. A fundamental limitation in the early treatment of JIA is that, while there are many options for therapies, there is no way of knowing objectively whether a particular therapy is effective for a patient. In fact, the treatment of JIA is often based on “trial and error” with changes to the regimen coming from subjective clinical examinations and patient surveys regarding pain and symptoms. Previous work in this field has focused on sensing movement of the joints only, which does not provide information on the underlying changes in physiology and structure that can occur with disease activity and progression. 

 

Intellectual merit

The project represents a significant advancement in the understanding and utilization of JAEs and electrical bioimpedance (EBI) for the assessment of joint health in JIA. Different joints were considered in this project; the knee, the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), and the wrist. We developed custom set-ups to accurately record JAEs from these three joints. We collected data from children with JIA and healthy children. We demonstrated that the sounds from the knee and TMJ are different between affected and unaffected joints. Similarly, we observed distinctions in the EBI signals recorded from the knee. Through the development and optimization of machine learning algorithms, we achieved accurate assessment of inflammation in the knee joint based on JAE data. We also studied asymmetric knee involvement in JIA, to provide deeper insights into disease severity assessment. Furthermore, a feasibility study on extracting frictional information from knee joint sounds has advanced our understanding of joint biomechanics and the potential applications of JAEs in assessing joint health across different anatomical sites. Overall, the intellectual merit of the project lies in its innovative approaches and contributions to advancing the scientific understanding of JAEs and their applications in assessing joint health across multiple conditions. This outcome of this research helps us better understand the sounds that result from joints affected by JIA and how they can tell us if a joint is healthy or inflamed, which could lead to better treatments and quality of life for these children. The research was tightly integrated with educational objectives, such as leveraging the Georgia Tech Opportunity Research Scholars program to involve undergraduate researchers from underrpresented groups in the project, mentored by the graduate student supported by the work. 

 

Broader Impacts

This project has contributed to the education of a diverse group of researchers, including 4 graduate students and 10 undergraduate students. The graduate students engaged in this project underwent comprehensive training encompassing various aspects, from traditional graduate study activities such as coursework and seminars to hands-on experience in collecting state-of-the-art benchtop JAEs and EBI. Additionally, they gained experience in developing advanced machine learning algorithms for assessing joint inflammation using the collected data. Their research findings have been disseminated through presentations at both local and national conferences, and they have been actively involved in drafting journal publications and dissertations. Furthermore, the graduate students have taken on mentoring roles, guiding undergraduate researchers in their respective projects. The team also learned about technology translation through a patent application resulting from the work in the project. Additionally, this project led to engagement with K-12 schools within the framework of the Georgia Tech GIFT program for K-12 teachers and students. This initiative was integrated into a summer project, successfully showcased at high school science fairs. This educational interaction significantly impacted the readiness and enthusiasm of high school students toward potential pursuits in STEM fields.
